page.title: 07THE ECOLOGY OF LOCHFOOT
page.content: THE ENVIRONMENT AROUND LOCHFOOT IS MAINLY FARMLAND,THE FLORA AND FAUNA TYPICAL OF SUCH.RABBITS CONTINUE TO CAUSE PROBLEMS TO FARMERS DESPITE THE PRESENCE OF FOXES.MOLES ARE TRAPPED REGULARLY ON FARMS.CROP SPRAYING AND THISTLE CUTTING ARE CARRIED OUT BUT ROADSIDES PRODUCE A WIDE VARIETY OF FLOWERS AND GRASSES.THE LOCH HAS A VARIED BIRD LIFE WITH COOTS,SWANS, GREBE,WATERHENS AND DUCK(MALLARD AND SHELD) NESTING.CORMORANT,HERON AND GREYLAG GEESE VISIT.UNFORTUNATELY, SHOOTERS HAVE SHOOTING RIGHTS WHEN THE GEESE COME.A PLANTATION OF SPRUCE GIVES SHELTER TO ROE DEER AND FOXES, AND A BADGER'S SETT HAS BEEN FOUND.AN OTTER WAS SIGHTED BY A BURN IN 1984. ALGAE HAS BEEN A PROBLEM,AN EXCESS IN 1983 CAUSING THE DEATHS OF MOST OF THE FISH.IN SPRING, FROGS AND TOADS MAKE A PERILOUS JOURNEY FROM VILLAGE TO LOCH.
